header.aside: A Chicken Spinoccoli (Spinach + Broccoli) Quiche dedicated to my physiotherapist Can P., the iron-man triathlete who loves cooking with spinach and broccoli. This Lila, Chop! savoury recipe is easy to make and does not require any protein powder.

section.p: Each time I travel back to Stockholm, I make it a point to visit my naprapath Can P., the best physio-massage therapist I have ever encountered. And every time he treats me, I hear his stomach growl, followed by an abashed but I just ate half a chocolate cake! How can I be hungry again? This iron-man triathlete, who has helped treat the worst of my injuries and muscle soreness, loves dark chocolate and dark green vegetables just like me, but with an unmatched appetite and a preference for real food— aka, no protein powder. I thus dedicate this savoury Chicken Spinoccoli Quiche à la Can to him. May it fuel his workouts and keep him full throughout the day!

tr.td: Pre-made pie crust pastry dough (I used Bio Pâte Brisée from the French supermarket, Casino), or

td.a: Gluten Free Pie Crust Plus Mix

tr.td: grated low-fat cheese (I used a Parmesan, emmental & mozzarella pizza cheese mix)

figure.figcaption: A healthy, hearty quiche, fresh from the oven.

section.p:
If you're in Sweden, you can find pie crust mixes online or in local groceries stores, such as Maizena pajdeg mix or Fryst Smördeg. If you're gluten intolerant, I recommend using a gluten-free mix such as
Grama's Pie Crust Plus or
Bob's Red Mill Pie Crust.

figure.figcaption: A slice of chicken Spinoccoli deliciousness

section.p: I always find that quiche tastes better the next day, so this makes a wonderful dish for left-overs. In fact, this quiche lasted us lunch and dinner for almost 3 days at home! Simply reheat in the oven (or in the microwave, but it might get a little soggy).

figure.figcaption: Garnish with more greens and olives... Bon appetite!

tr.td: Roll out pie pastry crust dough and place in a pie dish.
Heat a large frying pan with a dollop of vegetable oil, and cook chicken, broccoli and spinach until spinach is wilted and chicken is cooked through.
Transfer cooked chicken, broccoli and spinach into pastry-covered pie dish.
Cut up fresh mozzarella into small slices and place evenly throughout pie.
Mix eggs, egg whites, milk, and spices in a bowl.
Pour mixture over chicken and vegetables in the pie dish.
Bake at 200℃ until crust is lightly browned and egg mixture cooked.
Remove quiche from oven and let it sit so the consistency settles as firm.
Cut into slices, place on a plate, and garnish with salad, olives, or whatever your heart desires!

section.p: Remember, the thinner you bake your quiche, the more it will resemble pizza. If there is not enough liquid quiche-filling to cover all your ingredients, add more milk and egg-whites.
Using this basic quiche recipe, you can try different combinations of ingredients for exciting quiche variations, such as:

ul.li: Mediterranean Quiche – with aubergine, zucchini, olives, and feta cheese
Classic French (a healthier Quiche Lorraine) – with bacon, onions, spinach, and Gruyere cheese
Swedish Quiche (a healthier Västerbotten Paj) – with salmon, dill and västerbotton cheese
Thai Quiche (now we're talking!) – with Thai basil, chilli, green curry paste, and coconut milk (instead of milk)

section.p: ...and get a massage. If you're in Stockholm, check out Care of Body for the best physio-massage therapy from Mr. Can.

figure.figcaption: Quiche or pizza? Have both, healthily!
